criteria_text: Clarify the communication goals (conveying or receiving information, persuading, building trust or providing support) for an interaction
Facilitate communication among individuals, groups, and organizations
Identify when and how to initiate, conduct and close an interaction
Manage communication barriers (due to cognitive, physical or sensory impairment, culture, developmental stage, geography or language)
Support others to communicate for themselves

Manage the physical environment (physical environment: consider the impact of comfort, privacy, noise, space and temperature) for interactions considering the impact of comfort, privacy, noise, space and temperature
Communicate in an open, honest, clear and timely manner.
Work with patient advocates, cultural brokers or interpreters when indicated.
Identify and deliver key messages clearly, while keeping nerves under control.
Champion ethical, positive, sensitive and appropriate attitudes and behaviours in communicating, collaborating and participating with anybody and everybody.
Communicate in writing and orally with linguistic and cultural proficiency (e.g., using age-appropriate materials, incorporating images
Exercise cultural sensitivity in internal and external communication
Adapt the style, language and method of communication to the interaction
Maintain an approach to communication that is characterized by calmness, compassion, empathy, respect, sensitivity and tact
Seek to mitigate the impact of own beliefs, biases, emotional responses, opinions and values on verbal and non-verbal communication
Use relevant abbreviations, language and terminology, translating complex and clinical content into lay terms as necessary

Ensure that the literacy of populations served (e.g., ability to obtain, interpret, and use health and other information; social media literacy) is reflected in the organization’s policies, programs, and services
Use a range of verbal, non-verbal, visual, written and digital communication tools and techniques

Know how to write and tailor messages for different audiences e and has a basic understanding of the most effective style to use depending on ones' audience, media format and channel of communication.
Pay attention to the implications that language and culture have on what is communicated.
Construct meaning from visual images.
Demonstrate strong listening and communication skills
Use a range of non-verbal cues and verbal affirmations
Support others to ask questions and openly express experiences, feelings, ideas and opinions
Respond sensitively to what others express
Show empathy and genuine concern,e.g. by maintaining focus on the speaker, offering supportive comments, deferring judgement.
Show understanding with nonverbal cues (e.g. nodding, eye contact, leaning forward) and verbal affirmations.
Ask open-ended questions.
Paraphrase to show understanding.
Ask for clarification if necessary.
Is aware of online user behaviour and its implications for written content.
Provide relevant, accurate and complete information
Present information clearly, coherently, concisely and organized logically
Differentiate between information as facts, context-specific evidence, opinion and misinformation
Express own opinions and perspectives with clarity, confidence and respect
Adopt strategies that encourage a common understanding of information and decisions

Express your own opinions and perspectives with clarity, confidence and in a respectful manner (characterized by calmness, compassion, empathy, sensitivity and tact) that shows understanding for diversity (mitigating the impact of one’s own beliefs, biases, emotional responses, opinions and values as expressed through verbal and nonverbal communication)

Use relevant language (avoid abbreviations and complex/technical terminology/jargon, translate complex and clinical content into lay terms as necessary, consider the educational level of the person being spoken to) that is appropriate to different perspectives, situations, audiences and contexts.
Evaluate the effectiveness (e.g. by repeating information back to the individual, by asking questions) of communication approaches and adapt accordingly.
Anticipate, plan for, and deal with ambiguous and confusing situations.

Promote mutual understanding through appropriate use of communication approaches (verbal, nonverbal, visual, written, digital communication tools and techniques – depending on the audience and circumstances.).
Listen with attention and speaks with intention.
Use a range of health-related information management tools, including individual health records
Keep people informed about health risks and relevant aspects of their health care
Share information with relevant others in a timely manner
Comply with ethical and legal requirements for obtaining, recording, sharing, retaining and destroying information acquired in an occupational capacity
Share information consistent with informed consent, privacy and as required by protocol.
Use a range of health-related information management tools (including individual health records).
Prepare comprehensive and accurate health records
Engage with others across cultural, geographical, organizational and sectoral boundaries, and with individuals, caregivers, families and communities, as partners
Jointly negotiate roles and responsibilities to maximize strengths within a team
Fulfil agreed ways of working within the health team
Enable others to make their contribution to a team
Celebrate shared outcomes, goals and values
Collaborate with support networks, with the consent of the individual.
Assist individuals in accessing community resources.
Work together to address individuals’ needs.
Maintain constructive and collaborative working relationships with others, whether or not a formal team exists
Strive to develop a positive rapport with others characterized by respect, support and trust
Maintain ethical boundaries with other members of the health team
Minimize the impact of hierarchical differences on health outcome
Develop working relationships based on mutual trust, integrity and respect.
Promote teamwork and partnerships.
Work with different personalities across a variety of situations.
Understand others’ viewpoints.
Consider diverse, intercultural perspectives and working styles
Build equitable relationships.
Recognize personal efforts and the efforts of others
Seek to communicate in an inclusive and transparent manner.
Demonstrate willingness to learn from others’ experiences of the health system, health conditions and lived environment
Seek constructive, sensitive and timely feedback, support and advice
Provide constructive, sensitive and timely feedback, support and advice
Learn from interactions with others and feedback processes
Engage in opportunities to improve collaboration within and between teams
Work within the dynamics of a group.
Show commitment to the team’s purpose and goals
Consult with and/or refer to others as appropriate.
Engage in joint decision-making
Display behaviour and attitude that can be described as open-minded, empathic, curious, and appreciative of diverging perspectives and evidence.
Anticipate, identify, act upon and learn from tensions or potential areas of conflict
Focus on the sources of tensions rather than arising conflicts
Support a blame-free environment in which one is safe to question and seek support and guidance
Consider different perspectives when seeking compromise, consensus or a decision
Acknowledge diverse opinions.
Accept differences.
Show willingness to deal with interpersonal conflicts in a constructive, trustworthy way.
Provide the best possible health care that supports an approach to health services that is effective, equitable, efficient, inclusive, integrated, people centred, safe and timely

Adapt practice to the individual, family and community, including their physical, cognitive, cultural, emotional, linguistic, health literacy and sensory needs and other influences on their engagement with health services
Promote collaborative decision-making
Seek information and evidence from a range of sources when approaching decision-making
Approach decisions analytically and methodically
Adapt the approach to decision-making that reflects the complexity, urgency and consequences of decisions
Demonstrate critical thinking to reach decisions that are well reasoned, ethical, evidence informed, feasible, timely and based on the best available information
Use physical, human and financial resources efficiently
Avoid the overuse or misuse of resources
Organize own time and workload effectively
Take responsibility for own decisions and their consequences
Can differentiate categories of systems, e.g. natural, technological, and human.
Take initiative to mitigate anticipated problems
Focus on solutions, end goals and results
Create pragmatic solutions to identified problems
Conform to strategic aims and policies of the organization
Exhibit a curious mindset by listening openly with a 'tell me more' attitude and contributing with "what if..." approaches.
Can identify innovative ideas and creative solutions.
Can transfer ideas from one context into another.
Understand the difference between an idea and a solution.
Adjust priorities to respond to changing situations and demands
Demonstrate a calm demeanour under pressure
Use different styles of inquiry when one is stuck in one's thinking and needs to broaden one's perspective.
Demonstrate proactiveness and anticipation in shaping change and can adapt one's actions to changing circumstances and emerging evidence.

Describe the four ethical pillars for health: Beneficence, Nonmaleficence, Autonomy, and Justice, with Autonomy cited as the basis for informed consent, truth-telling, and confidentiality (e.g. see Varkey B. Principles of Clinical Ethics and Their Application to Practice. Med Princ Pract. 2021;30(1):17-28. doi: 10.1159/000509119. Epub 2020 Jun 4. PMID: 32498071; PMCID: PMC7923912.)

Describe ethical principles for digital health, particularly algorithms and decision-making in digital health and AI, that help ensure the safe, ethical and equitable provision of health care, such as (not exhaustive list): * fairness * accountability * transparency * explainability * human oversight / human-in-the-loop
Ask critical questions to identify ethical values at stake and potential ethical challenges or problems
Identify ethical values at stake by thinking out of the box with a critical attitude
Explain relevant concepts and learn how to formulate logically sound arguments

Analyze ethical frameworks and values from the local culture for implications for the design, implementation and sustainability of digital health systems (e.g. African and Asian cultures' greater emphasis on community and relationships vs Western focus on individualism)
Recognise that multiple values might potentially be conflicting with one another
Establish a process to deconstruct the complexity of ethical dilemmas
Consider that more than one valid point of view could exist
Gather all the necessary facts and the details about the situation/case
Establish processes and allocated dedicated time for a reiterative thinking process
Support an open environment where asking questions and being reflective is encouraged
Provide tools and resources that facilitate resolution of ethical dilemmas (e.g., existing ethical frameworks)
Ensure continuous training and expanding digital knowledge activities
Monitor decision making processes, allowing for adaptation and corrections
Apply ethical principles while engaging in critical thinking
Provide sound recommendations using critical thinking skills and based on evidence and/or best practices

Identify each stakeholder, including those who may be directly or indirectly impacted such as patients and populations and the health providers, and those who are directly or indirectly responsible for the digital health implementation
Describe, per each stakeholder perspective, intentions, motivations and principles underneath it, as well as short/long term consequences
Identify the priorities of each stakeholder
Distinguish one’s own perspectives, values, interests and motivations from those of other stakeholders
Report on potential conflict of interests on stakeholders’ perspectives

Describe the recent local, national, regional and/or international frameworks, guidelines, policies, principles, and strategies that cover ethics of digital health, including AI, for your given context/organization, such as:

- Principles of Digital Development - DPI Safeguards Framework - WHO guidance on ethics and governance of AI for health (several documents) - African Union Continental Strategy on AI - UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of AI - OECD AI Principles - G20 AI Principles - NIST AI Risk Management Framework

Describe the recent local, national and/or international regulations and laws that address specific ethics issues of digital health, usually data protection and AI regulation, for your given context/organization, for example:
- GDPR - EU AI Act - EU Digital Services Act - US HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act) - South Africa POPIA (Protection of Personal Information Act)

Set up an adverse event / incident management and reporting reporting system and processes that include the policies and requirements for reporting, notification, mitigation measures, and tracking to resolution

Create review or advisory boards and update IRB processes for the ethical and equitable development and governance of the digital health intervention for the given context (e.g. local, national) or organization

Define methods for redress for the harm, such as: - Establish or update ombudsman or other focal point and accompanying processes for anyone (public, staff, etc) to report potential ethical harm or inequity arising from the digital health system
Identify instances where multiple interests conflict with the completion of the project as intended.
Identify instances where multiple relationships might occur between participants in a digital health project that could create or give the impression of a conflict of interest
Establish a structure, processes and policies to fairly address conflicts of interest at the outset of digital health projects.
Implement processes to identify conflicts of interest at the outset of digital health projects.
Monitor digital health projects to ensure conflicts of interest do not arise, or if necessary, do not interfere with the course of a project.
Report and/or disclose any potential or actual conflicts of interest as required
Respond to conflicts of interest as required and according to processes and policies in place
Identify parties to whom participants in a digital health system or initiative are accountable.
Identify specific activities and outcomes for which participants in a digital health system or initiative are accountable.
Identify consequences for breaches of accountability.
Report or disclose any breaches of accountability as required
Establish processes for identifying and addressing issues for which parties are to be held accountable, such as a digital health independent review board (IRB) (similar to a research IRB)
Respond to breaches of accountability according to the process and mechanisms in place
Support accountability mechanisms throughout the digital health system life cycle when under pressure
Describe health equity, health inequality, and the social determinants of health cited by WHO and other health institutions
Describe the human right to health and gender equality, disability inclusion and other categories of bias based on identity including sexuality, age, class, race, caste, religion, language
Describe the impacts of multiple and intersecting forms of discrimination on health and the ethical implications of developing and deploying digital solutions without considering equity

Summarize the digital divide: its history, why it exists, and types of divides such as: * Availability - lack of internet, power, computers, phones, etc * Affordability * Quality of service * Relevance (cultural / local relevance) * Digital literacy and education at all ages * Gender (e.g. technology viewed as a male field; male head of household controls the mobile phone)
Apply the Principles for Digital Development to ensure digital health solution is sustainable and inclusive

Explain how technology is not neutral: it can have political effects and reinforce social hierarchies and biases, societal or political power structures, intentionally or not; it can create or exacerbate inequalities and power asymmetries, all of which affects who benefits from digital health-enabled services (e.g. EMRs implemented only in higher resource areas where there is reliable power and internet (digital redlining); those who can afford smartphones vs those who do not)
Recognize that the dominance of a few Global North companies in business tech software such as email, office software and cloud services creates dependencies and therefore vulnerabilities

Describe the concept of digital colonialism, digital and data sovereignty, which includes data exploitation (e.g. WorldCoin), extractive data collection and data labeling in low-wage countries to train AI, to the transfer of mineral wealth from the Global South to produce electronics
Describe the historic and contemporary socio-cultural context, practices and beliefs that can bias decisions and evidence.

Articulate the mechanisms of how historical and contemporary socio-cultural bias may be embedded explicitly or implicitly in primary and secondary data sources and algorithms being used in digital health (e.g., variable definitions, variables included or excluded, rationale or evidence used to justify inclusion/exclusion of variables, data gathering processes, and data use) and lead to harms and exclusions by sociocultural biased decisions of digital health algorithms.
Identify how digital health and AI solutions, models and algorithms designed for and/or based on data from the Global North may not give relevant or correct results for the LMIC context

Recognize risks and harms to individuals, groups and systems from socio-cultural bias and discrimination embedded or encoded in digital health (including AI) design, testing, training, and implementation which can impact clinical decision-making, patient care (clinician understanding of patients’ needs, clinician-patient interactions, and quality of care provided to patients), service delivery, resource allocation, patient outcomes for populations that experience sociocultural bias, and overall society when there is uneven burden of disease across populations
Identify determinants of access to a given digital health offering among members of the public (e.g. rural vs urban, socioeconomic status).
Identify design and performance requirements to ensure it is accessible to the end users using methods that engage the intended end users

Identify technological supports and institutional and structural factors (e.g., internet/mobile network availability, device charge locations) and non-technological supports (e.g., cost, health and digital literacy training) necessary for the public to access and use a digital health solution and devices and which can facilitate or create barriers to these determinant of access and use of digital health
Employ socio-cultural approaches for designing and building equitable digital health systems and minimizing the possible risks and harms, thereby creating socio-cultural awareness, such as:

- consult diverse stakeholders throughout the life cycle, from concept to maintenance and monitoring; - leverage intermediaries who have a closer relationship to the beneficiary, client or patient to act as explainers and liaisons like CHWs, midwives, village leaders - adopt participatory, human-centered design, e.g. design with and by community members, not for them

Use an intersectoral approach to mitigate against the impact of multiple and intersecting factors of vulnerability (gender, disability, age, ethnicity and other factors of discrimination) on the use of digital health and whether it impacts health equity and outcomes

Apply the basic ethical principles in the Belmont Report to identify the ethical implications of not using digital health in a way that supports care in an equitable manner (e.g., the “do no harm” component of beneficence, the unequal treatment component of justice)

Incorporate ethical evaluation into the entire development lifecycle, using specific technical approaches, such as (AI subset provided as this is an evolving field): - model cards - RLHF - reinforcement learning with human feedback - red teaming - algorithmic audits - federated learning - edge AI

Use frameworks, tools, and platforms for testing responsible AI (subset provided as this is an evolving field): - NIST AI Risk Management Framework - Singapore AI Verify - responsible AI validation platforms from private companies
Investigate newer technologies and approaches such as data trusts and blockchain as methods for ensuring data integrity and transparency for the appropriate use case

Acquire funds to address digital inequity which will exacerbate health inequities, such as: - invest in resilient local digital infrastructure (connectivity, power, redundancy) - invest in local digital health and AI staff skills building and companies
Apply inclusive/universal design: design for all people, all abilities, flexible and adaptible
Identify privacy and surveillance risks from biometric identification tools such as facial recognition, fingerprint ID, GPS tracking
Describe the requirements for documenting informed consent
Describe the process for documenting informed consent
Conduct process for obtaining informed consent
Maintain administrative, technical, and physical safeguards for authorization
Establish security audit process
Navigate the balance the privacy and security of health information and data with improved healthcare delivery, health technology development, health system management, and resource utilization
Assess blind spots for harm prevention
Adhere to ethical principles in implementation and development of digital health tools
Act with honesty, integrity and transparency
Uphold legal and ethical principles, including capacity, confidentiality, consent, conflict of interest, duty of care, dignity, privacy and safeguarding
Consult with others in situations with ethical implications
Refuses individual gifts or other forms of influence intended to coerce or invite personal favour
Support people to develop their health literacy
Demonstrate respect for the autonomy, goals, perspectives, preferences, priorities and rights of individuals, caregivers, families and communities
Support people to develop strategies or access tools to manage their own health and well-being
Demonstrate compassion, empathy and respect for all people
Adoptsan approach to practice that is non-blaming, non-discriminatory, non-judgemental and non-stigmatizing
Maintain self-awareness around own beliefs, biases, emotional responses and values
Demonstrates cultural sensitivity
Embraces individual differences and cultural diversity
Challenges the causes and consequences of discrimination, exclusion, prejudice, stigma and other barriers to accessing and utilizing health services
Support people to challenge or address their economic, environmental, political and social determinants of health
Support people to manage their health within health system constraints and their determinants of health
Incorporate health promotion and disability, disease and injury prevention into interactions
Support individuals, caregivers, families and communities to adopt healthy behaviours
Contribute to protecting vulnerable populations
Adhere to safety protocols that avoid adverse events, health care errors, and incidents of harm and unsafe practice
Learn from what works and what has not gone well
Offer suggestions for improvement to address identified problems
Participate in quality measurement and continuous quality improvement processes

Describe historical and contemporary examples of health IT interventions and programs that have been sustainable and unsustainable, intervention/program management factors that contributed to (un)sustainability, and the ethical and equity factors that contributed to program sustainability success or failure, especially within developing countries and communities that are systematically underserved and marginalized

Identify relevant health IT, digital equity, and/or program sustainability frameworks and strategies to identify factors that are key contributors to sustainability and that can be used to develop new inverventions/programs or evaluate and improve existing interventions/programs, especaially from an ethical and equity perspective

Identify mechanisms in which health information technologies contribute to climate change and enviornmental disasters, such as the intensive resources needed to power digital and AI infrastructure; and the digital value chain from the extraction of critical minerals to the dumping of e-waste

Identify how climate and enviornmental hazards can negatively impact access to and functioning of health IT, especially for satety net/public healthcare organizations and populations that are disproportionately impacted by climate change and enviornmental disasters
Identify strategies to support health IT resilliance to climate change and enironmental disasters
Identify mechanisms in which health information technologies can mitigate climate change

Identify strategies for using health IT to support disaster preparadness and disaster responses that are equitable especially among populatons disproportionatley impacted by climate change and enviornmental disasters
Consider the energy use, carbon footprint, and resource requirements of digital health systems when proposing, planning, or approving new projects, policies, or technologies
Evaluate energy efficiency specifications when selecting hardware, software, and cloud services for digital health initiatives
Incorporate environmental sustainability criteria into vendor selection processes and technology procurement decisions
Consider environmental factors when making decisions about data center locations, server infrastructure, and network architecture
Apply energy-efficient practices in data management, such as optimizing data storage, reducing unnecessary data transfers, and scheduling resource-intensive processes during off-peak hours
Promote sustainable use of digital tools by establishing guidelines for appropriate technology use (e.g., when to use computationally intensive AI/ML models versus simpler solutions)
Advocate for renewable energy sources and energy-efficient cooling systems in digital health facility planning
Develop and implement policies for responsible disposal and recycling of electronic equipment and devices
Plan for equipment lifecycle management that maximizes useful life while minimizing environmental waste
Track and measure environmental metrics (energy consumption, carbon footprint, e-waste generation) related to digital health activities
Communicate environmental impact data to stakeholders and use findings to inform continuous improvement of sustainability practices
Adjust operations to improve sustainability based on monitoring results
Encourage the use of energy-efficient hardware, cloud services, and software within the organization or project, and advocate for minimizing environmental impact in daily operations.

Participate in, contribute to, or lead the development and implementation of organizational policies and national guidelines for sustainable digital health operations (such as responsible e-waste management and sustainable procurement).
Raise awareness among team members, partners, and stakeholders about environmentally responsible digital health practices, and foster a culture of sustainability.
Conduct horizon/foresight scanning of events
Identify emerging issues for digital health
Clearly define the problem, objective/goal and scope of the proposed policy, regulation or governance
Produce an analysis of evidence needs and gaps to inform further action
Gather evidence to frame the issue or fill knowlege gaps

Analyze the regulatory or policy impact for digital health within the given context/institution of new action plans, agendas, agreements, blueprints, master plans, mechanisms, roadmaps and strategies such as WHO Global Strategy on Digital Health, Global Financing Facility (GFF), International Health Regulations, Africa Health Strategy 2016–2030 (African Union), Asia Pacific Health Security Action Framework (APHSAF), etc.

Analyze implications for digital health of existing, new or revised policies, regulations or governance such as those for AI, data privacy and protection; digital and data sovereignty; product and service liability; information transparency; human rights, IP/copyright law, cybersecurity.
Prepare briefings and speeches related to digital health using plain language, analogies, storytelling and other techniques to explain technical concepts in a clear, relatable and succinct way
Study multiple strategies to identify the optimum policy, regulation or governance approach
Advise or design options or interventions fit to sustainably address a policy, regulatory or governance issue, applying best available evidence and data as well as latest design methods.
Plan, design, and execute an evaluation of a policy, regulatory or governance intervention

Use a regulatory sandbox to test regulations during their drafting or development, providing a safe space for experimentation with digital health solutions and regulatory learning before regulations are finalized or broadly implemented
Articulate the digital health implications of the options, including evidence, trade-offs, spill-over effects, limitations and uncertainties, comprehensively and accurately.
Align with digital health strategy at the organization, local, or national level and/or international level such as WHO Digital Health Strategy
Integrate lessons, best practices and exemplars in digital health into draft policies, regulations, or governance mechanisms

Consult diverse stakeholder and expert groups, such as other digital and data governance bodies, health informatics associations, digital health communities of practice, NGO implementers, the private sector, ICT and telecom sector and others (e.g. legal, finance and education sectors) as relevant to gather input, feedback and gain buy-in.
Obtain resources for implementation (human, financial, physical)
Procure necessary digital technologies, systems and service contracts to support the new policy, regulation or governance mechanism
Establish separate governance and oversight body, governing structure and processes (may be external)

Disseminate, inform and educate on policy, regulation or governance mechanisms especially with stakeholders such as the health and digital health leaders in the health system, private sector, other digital and data governance bodies, health informatics associations, NGO implementers, digital health communities of practice, etc.
Monitor to ensure correct and complete implementation
Apply change management methodologies to facilitate adoption
Set accountability standards and performance expectations to ensure consistent adherence to policies, regulations and governance mechanisms
Address politically sensitive areas that affect the adoption of the policy, regulation or governance area, such as data sovereignty, data ownership, privacy concerns, etc.
Assess the effectiveness and success of the policy, regulation or governance mechanism.

Monitor to determine if the policy, regulation or governance mechanism can continue as is or should be updated or terminated if deemed redundant, accomplished, or ineffective, based on evidence and data
Develop KPIs and reporting mechanisms
Produce KPI reports
Develop the monitoring and compliance mechanisms
Monitor compliance
Support and answer questions
Review processes that apply to ones' job
Comply with any governance requirements, policies, regulations
Complete required training and documentation per the policies, regulations, KPis, etc.
Establish strategic objectives to guide long-term goals and priorities for use of digital solutions
Conduct landscape review of digital health implementations within the given context/institution
Integrate technology with organizational strategies.
Develop roll out plans.
Establish and Practice strategic thinking process to effectively lead the team to achieve the vision.

Align the digital health strategy with new action plans, agendas, agreements, blueprints, master plans, mechanisms, roadmaps and strategies such as WHO Global Strategy on Digital Health, PAHO Regional Digital Health Strategy for the Americas, Africa CDC Digital Transformation Strategy, Regional Action Framework on Digital Health in the Western Pacific, etc. as relevant to the given context/institution
Plan implementation activities aligned with digital health strategy
Identify and allocate resources required for implementation activities
Lead and manage digital health initatives according to implementation plan
Sensitize the digital health strategies to the relevant stakeholders
Adapt existing or create new health and ICT policies, frameworks, etc. in accordance with the digital health strategies.
Facilitate the change management process necessary to implement the digital health strategies within the organization
Develop monitoring and evaluation lifecycle and KPIs
Define the purpose and the scope of the digital health strategy M/E mechanism
Identify an appropriate framework to monitor and evaluate the digital health strategy
Develop a logic model for the digital health strategy implementation
Determine what key performance indicators need to be monitored to evaluate the digital health strategy
Collect and analyze data keeping in mind the specific requirements for dissemination and reporting
Leverage the data to make course corrections and refinements.
Develop and implement a negotiation strategy for a digital health strategy, transformation plan, policy initiative, etc.
Communicate effectively at the negotiation table and outside.
Create, convey and rebut arguments.
Anticipate technological trends alongside global health and other trends (e.g. economic, environmental, demographic)
Interpret the "big picture" to see beyond current capabilities for digital technology to improve health outcomes
Create a clear, compelling digital vision
Create clear roadmaps that align digital initiatives with institutional goals
Determine how to balance short-term wins with long-term transformation
Foster an environment where calculated experimentation and risk-taking and learning from failure are encouraged and rewarded, as feasible within the health system
Provide space for brainstorming, human-centered design and other techniques to reveal new or refine insights about the utility of digital technology and novel digital health approaches or solutions

Advocate for and support the adoption of innovative digital practices within health contexts, including making the case for investment or resource allocation to pilot promising solutions and larger digital innovation initiatives
Foster continuous, evidence-based improvement and evolution

Map key expertise, change agents and knowledge brokers in the domains that pertain to the digital health initiative including but not limited to the public and private health sector, national health insurance or social protection commission, health informatics associations, digital health communities of practice, NGO implementers, ICT and telecom sector and others (e.g. business, legal, finance and education sectors)
Convene stakeholders and create opportunities for interdisciplinary exchange
Create a coalition of leadership to lead the digital transformation or strategy from ideation to implementation
Cultivate an informal digital health expert network that continuously exchanges with the institution and/or relevant organizations and communities
Share state of the art expertise and evidence, and examples of success and failure for mutual learning.
Identify a senior level leader who understands the value of digital health and is well-respected to act as the project champion

Conduct readiness assessments covering skills, culture/attitudes, existing systems, ongoing and planned projects, technology infrastructure, and procurement and other business processes to assess the size, nature and impact of organisational change as a result of the digital health implementation

Advocate for and secure resources (financial, human, technology, physical) to successfully institute the organizational changes necessitated by the digital health implementation, such as new job positions, revised salary structure, new department, new facilities, new technology, service contracts, etc.

Lead change management processes for digital health implementations, including developing adoption strategies, addressing resistance, and facilitating smooth transitions from traditional to digital workflows
Foster a culture of openness to change, humility, learning and sharing ideas between health and digital health staff
Exemplify a sense of comfort with ambiguity and uncertainty given the constantly evolving digital health and technology sector and unpredictable state of health and financing and world at large
Lead the development of comprehensive stakeholder management strategies and plans.

Work with all interested parties to identify stakeholders in the domains that pertain to the digital health initiative including but not limited to the public and private health sector, national health insurance or social protection commission, health informatics associations, digital health communities of practice, NGO implementers, ICT and telecom sector and others (e.g. business, legal, finance and education sectors)
Determine the strategic approach to understanding stakeholder objectives and requirements.
Establish and promote the overall vision for how stakeholder objectives are met and determine organisational roles and alignment.
Build and manage long-term, strategic and effective relationships with senior stakeholders (internal and external).
Facilitate the engagement of stakeholders in support of the delivery of digital health services and change projects.
Act as a single point of contact for senior stakeholders, facilitating relationships between them, and as the ultimate escalation point for issue resolution..
Negotiate to ensure that stakeholders understand and agree on what will meet their needs, and that appropriate agreements are defined.
Oversee monitoring of relationships including lessons learned and appropriate feedback.
Lead actions to improve relations and open communications with and between stakeholders.
Establish a steering, oversight or governing committee for digital health
Oversee / Manage the digital health implementation through the entire system development life cycle
Supervise digital health solution and service vendors to satisfactorily provide the solution or services and ongoing support in compliance with the contract
Apply processes of organizing, planning, leading, decision-making, and controlling resources in alignment with the overall digital health direction and strategic priorities of the organization.
Calculate/estimate the Total Cost of Ownership (TCO)

Estimate impact on labor and the workforce, such as change in digital health jobs (increase in digital health jobs, reduction in entry level jobs, e.g. data entry clerk), growth and investment in digital health companies, etc.
Identify proxy data for impact estimations

Conduct studies, such as time and motion studies, to measure savings in time, workflow/process, and staff; supply chain impact (e.g. reduced stockouts of medicines and supplies), more efficient resource utilization, etc.

Measure improvements to health service delivery, such as faster diagnosis and treatment, reduction in diagnostic errors, faster recovery, fewer readmissions to clinic/hospital, increased survival rate, fewer adverse events
Evaluate quality of care through qualitative methods such as surveys, spot checks
Measure prevalence of disease, mortality, morbidity, etc at the population level; DALYs, QALYs, etc.
Map and identify existing resources and examples of similar costed plans for digital health
Map the donor landscape for focus, strategy and level of investment in digital health
Calculate the Total Cost of Ownership (TCO)
Build the business case
Forecast funding needs for the next 5+ years
Develop the investment roadmap

Convene a working group to develop the investment / funding strategy, build buy-in, and develop an advocacy strategy, including stakeholders and actors such as health and digital health leaders from the ministry of health, national health insurance commission, donors, health informatics associations, digital health communities of practice in the NGO and private sectors
Map and Identify potential sources of funding
Execute fundraising/funding application processes, such as preparing concept notes, proposals, work plans and budgets

Validate budgets against work plans and vice versa to ensure every digital health-related cost is included for the corresponding work, e.g. for an EMR implementation, check the proposal budget for software license and technical support, hosting, staff, consultants/vendors, training, infrastructure upgrades, software customizations, etc.
Maintain donor and funder relationships
Implement financial oversight systems
Develop routine processes for managing digital health budgets and expenditures
Obtain and disburse the funds in compliance with regulatory, organizational and/or donor requirements.

Monitor expenditures to ensure that they are used appropriately and in compliance with all regulations, and product/service is received, in particular payment against digital health product (hardware and software), service, support, and consulting contracts; related digital infrastructure services (e.g. cloud hosting, mobile network operator agreements).
Prepare and deliver grant reporting to grant funders
Assess and advise using a systems approach in the identification of tools and/or functions that alleviate and address current health service challenges
Work within the the complexity of clinical/non-clinical workflows within the regional and national health care systems
Design and implement collaborative partnerships/ownership agreements between tools/organizations/primary stakeholders (e.g. data sharing, data ownership, revenue generation, etc.)
Apply health economic evaluation and strategy to determine cost effectiveness, ROI, health impact of tools/service within a health system

Identify and Clarify Needs: Detect missing key information in data requests and seek clarification as needed.

Recognise and act upon digital situations and events that might compromise personal, professional or organisational security

Promote a culture of device security awareness by actively reminding colleagues of best practices, emerging risks, and the importance of protecting all types of devices used in healthcare settings
